awd_titl_txt: Neurobiologically-informed risk assessment: An empirical examination
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to anticipate who will reoffend, relapse, or recover is an important responsibility of clinical and legal practitioners and a prerequisite for the provision of effective healthcare and social services to adjudicated individuals with different risk-needs. It is widely accepted that the brain plays an essential role in shaping antisocial behaviors, but the precise nature of these processes is poorly understood. Previous scholarship has raised the possibility that methods of assessing risk in adjudicated individuals could be improved by including measures of brain function along with traditional behavioral and social measures. This project examines whether the inclusion of noninvasive brain measures can enhance the ability to correctly distinguish between those inmates most and least likely to experience antisocial outcomes, such as rearrest. The project also supports the training and professional development of students in cognitive neuroscience. The results of this project are expected to support the development of clinical tools, procedures and treatments for assessing and remediating risk in forensic populations, thereby reducing the associated costs to society. 
 
The objectives of this project are achieved by conducting the first large, out-of-sample longitudinal test of a neurocognitive model of persistent antisocial behavior. The model is developed in a sample of 600 adult criminal offenders who have undergone task-driven functional magnetic resonance imaging and been assessed for reoffense risk 12 months following release from prison (the training sample). This model is then used to classify a separate sample of 100 criminal offenders who are similarly scanned, released, and followed (the testing sample). The project employs both theory-driven (null hypothesis testing of a neurocognitive model of impulse control) and data-driven (e.g., whole-brain machine learning classification) analytical approaches. This project will advance basic and clinical knowledge of how neurobiological and behavioral risk factors interact to produce antisocial behavior by characterizing their combined and relative utility in assessing risk. This knowledge can, in turn, be used to inform the development of treatment approaches that are more sensitive to individual defendants' unique risk needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Despite decades of research examining the brain?s contributions to the propensity for antisocial behavior, this process is still poorly understood, owing in part to the highly complex relationship between the brain, behaviors, and the dynamic environmental contexts in which they operate. This project investigated how brain physiology shapes prosocial and antisocial behavior. Specifically, it examined the utility of a neurocognitive model of impulse control to enhance predictions of reoffense risk and characterize some of the dynamic factors that dispose people toward or protect them against particular types of persistent antisocial behavior.

To do so, the investigators conducted the first out-of-sample test of the predictive validity of a previously developed neurocognitive model of impulse control (see Aharoni et al., 2013, 2014; Allen et al., 2022a) to predict rearrest. The investigators validated the locations of theorized impulsivity-related brain networks, and tested their predictive utility in a sample of 500 adult criminal offenders who were assessed for rearrest after undergoing  functional magnetic resonance imaging during participation in an impulse control task. The neurocognitive model demonstrated incremental predictive utility of both neurobiological and behavioral risk factors, while accounting for potential sex differences (Allen et al., 2022a). In addition to this hypothesis-driven analysis, we developed a separate, data-driven (e.g., machine learning) protocol to test classification accuracy in rearrest across the whole brain. While our results demonstrate the feasibility and promise of machine-learning models for mapping brain function and predicting associated antisocial behaviors, the predictive accuracy of these models generally did not outperform simpler hypothesis driven models, suggesting that these different approaches may have different strengths for exploratory versus confirmatory analyses.

Broadly, this project advanced knowledge by showing how an understanding of brain activity associated with a particular behavioral trait (i.e., impulse control) may improve the ability to predict and explain particular types of persistent antisocial behavior. The results have (1) contributed to a broad spectrum of scholarly literature in cognitive neuroscience, criminology, mental health, and bioethics, with special focus on error monitoring theories of impulsive antisocial behaviors, by way two peer-reviewed publications, one peer-reviewed commentary, two book chapters, one doctoral dissertation, fifteen national or international presentations, and additional manuscripts in preparation. This project also (2) underscored the value of integrating biological, psychological, and sociological frameworks in the explanation and prediction of antisocial behavior, and will support the development of clinical tools for assessing and remediating risk in forensic populations by creating an imaging-to-analysis machine learning pipeline intended to characterize individual risk (Aharoni et al., 2019; Aharoni et al., 2022; Allen et al., 2022a).

Through this project, we also educated public and professional audiences with interests in the management of high risk behavior by conducting translational research that engages with broader audiences. By presenting the results of this research in a series of talks to lay and professional audiences, we have emphasized both the scientific innovations and limitations of this work as well as the potential ethical implications of its use in criminal justice settings. This project has also supported the education and professional development of undergraduate and graduate students in cognitive neuroscience, including the conferment of a doctoral degree and a postdoctoral fellowship. Students involved in the project received training in longitudinal and experimental study design, fMRI data acquisition, survival analysis, machine learning, technical writing, and presented at meetings and conferences. Ultimately, the results of this research will facilitate the development of treatment approaches that are tailored specifically to offenders? unique risk-needs, which carry the potential to improve treatment efficacy and reduce associated costs to society.
